Award.AwardTitle: A Pre-treatment Routine for Correcting Age-Offsets on AMS Radiocarbon Dated Ceramic Residue

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Donna C. Roper, from Kansas State University, and Dr. Linda Scott Cummings, from PaleoResearch Institute, will collaborate on a study designed to develop a pre-treatment protocol for correcting age-offsets on AMS radiocarbon dated ceramic residue. Since its introduction in the mid-twentieth century, radiocarbon dating has been vital to archaeologists as well as biologists, geologists and scientists conducting basic and applied research in other fields. The method has seen considerable advancement in the ensuing decades, enabling development of evermore accurate and precise timelines. Capable of producing high precision dates, the AMS technique permits assay of small materials, such as individual corn kernel fragments or seeds that are short-lived and contemporaneous with their context, thus yielding ages with higher accuracy than ever before. Also, the range of organic materials believed to be appropriate for archaeological dating is broadened. Charred food burned onto ceramic vessels during cooking, often termed ceramic residue, is one of the materials now commonly selected for dating and increasingly used in North America, Europe, and Asia. As its use increases, ceramic residue ages are often noted to be older than dates on other short-lived material from the same context, and thus are not accurate. Continuing to assume the accuracy of these dates and integrating them into timelines degrades chronologies precisely at the time the discipline is able to produce timelines of moderately high resolution and enable archaeologists to work toward viable narratives of historical process.
Two previous approaches to addressing the problem have included determining chemical composition as a predictor of which samples likely are affected, and developing correction factors for ages. Neither is proving capable of satisfactorily addressing the problem; indeed, recent conclusions regarding correction factors are that age offsets are too variable for any single local, or regional correction factor to be accurate. The study team for this project proposes a third approach that includes a pre-treatment protocol to remove and discard compounds responsible for the anomalous dates. As a result, dates may be obtained on a fraction of residue shown to produce dates contemporaneous with associated short-lived materials. Limited trials have produced encouraging results toward developing a ceramic residue treatment protocol for general use. AMS dates on residue and on context materials known to produce accurate ages will be paired to test the efficacy of the developing method. Tests will consist of dating multiple fractions, including removed compounds, from a few residues to obtain information concerning the old carbon content. Samples will be drawn from late prehistoric individual dwellings in the North American Great Plains that had use-lives on the order of a decade to a decade-and-a-half. Testing and vetting methods aims toward development of a pre-treatment protocol capable of obtaining accurate dates on ceramic residue anywhere in the world, as residues are fast becoming a significant part of the radiocarbon dating record. Furthermore, this method will lead to a future effort involving chemical separation of compounds containing old carbon in or adhering to other materials, opening the door to application of this protocol to additional samples so they may produce accurate and concordant radiocarbon dates.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
AMS radiocarbon dating annual plant remains and charred food residues on single-use pottery are the best methods to accurately date an archaeological site’s occupation; however, there are some assumptions that need to be addressed.

 

Annual plant remains include tree nuts and herbaceous plant seeds that are invaluable for radiocarbon dating because they represent one year’s growth.  Wood charcoal radiocarbon dates are offset, depending on dating outermost or inner growth rings, and have an “Old Wood Effect” that produces ages hundreds of years older than the site’s occupation. Were annual plant remains always available, “old wood” errors wouldn’t occur; however, because annual plant fossils are rare, archaeologists use charred food crusts to date their “single-year-of-use.”  Pottery is abundant compared to annual macrofossils and contains charred food crust residues (CFC’s), different from soluble food residues soaked into vessels, yielding “single-year-dates”.

 

Archaeologists assume food crust 14C dates are the pottery’s exact year of use ¾ the archaeological occupation date. This premise is valid if foods are short-lived terrestrial plants and animals with 1-10 yr. life spans and in equilibrium with atmospheric CO2.  Many foods, e.g., fish, mollusks, crustaceans, and aquatic plants, derive their carbon from sources not in equilibrium with the atmosphere and yield radiocarbon ages older than their death-year ¾ the “aquatic reservoir effect.”  Our research focuses on how 14C ages differ when foods are terrestrial, aquatic or both. 

 

Middle Missouri Village ceramics date 100-200 yr. “too old” relative to associated maize.  Consequently, Dr. Stan Ahler rejected all charred food crust dates. We examined published, dated food crust from Brainerd ware from central Minnesota, where ages are 1000-2000 yr. older than typological ages.  Because annual plant remains were rare, we focused on chemical pretreatments to correct new dates.

 

A study through MNHS funded by the Minnesota Statewide Survey of Historical and Archaeological Sites (Cummings 2017) tested 14C-dated fish species from various trophic levels whose specimens were collected in 1939 AD, i.e., pre-atomic bomb testing. Bottom-feeding catfish had the most 14C depletion, dating 1225 BP (725 AD); walleye pike, which eats larval and adult insects, had less 14C depletion, dating circa 307 BP (1640 AD).  Two fish species yielded intermediate ages, indicating the upper Mississippi River Basin had considerable age offsets for charred food crusts.

 

Our project goals were: 1) Determine causes for age offsets between CFCs and associated annual plants, 2) Test if older carbon contaminated charred food crust, 3) Identify chemical signatures indicating whether or not ancient carbon could be removed, and 4) test sherds from different regions and test multiple treatments on CFC from single sherds.

 

Near-infinite combinations of foods constitute CFCs accumulating above the vessel’s water line. The term “charred food” crust includes charred food and well-cooked, oxidized food particles and compounds. 

 

Carbohydrates burn at low temperatures while proteins burn at higher temperatures, but do become part of the food crust as they dry and contribute to the crust accumulating above the water line. Fats and lipids do not burn, but become incorporated into the porous charred food crust. Because proteins oxidize and dehydrate, they are removable using standard 14C pretreatments or chloroform/methanol treatments used in tandem with standard pretreatments.  Fats and lipids do not burn and are removable.  Dating this charred food crust is different than dating dairy fatty acids that soak into ceramics and are recovered and separated for 14C dating (Casanova et al 2020). 

 

Archaeologists and museum curators from the United States provided macroflora and associated ceramics for comparative radiocarbon dating.  Over the grant’s duration we received ceramics with food crust and their associated annual plants from central Plains, the upper Midwest, northeastern and southeastern US, and central Atlantic states. We examined CFC from multiple positions on the same vessel.  Finally, we used ceramics with enough charred food crust for repetitive analyses with differing solvents.

 

Dates on charred food crusts from different locations on a single cooking vessel vary by 100-500 years.  Commonly, the youngest and most accurate ages are from the rim, while the oldest dates are below the rim.

 

Because food crust dates were usually older than dates on associated annual plants, we concluded that charred food crusts contain ancient carbon.  After chloroform/methanol extractions removed fats, lipids, and soluble proteins, most CFC dates were nearly identical to those on associated annual plants. Discordant dates were explained as containing proteins too charred to remove with chemical pretreatment.

 

Neither chemical extraction with urea nor 6N HCl hydrolysis before acid-base-acid pretreatment improved the accuracy of food crust 14C dates.

 

In conclusion, chloroform/methanol preceding acid-base-acid pretreatment was the only method that removed ancient carbon from food crusts.

 

References:

 

Casanova, E., et al. 2020 Accurate compound-specific 14C dating of archaeological pottery vessels.  Nature, 580:505-510.    

Cummings, Linda Scott, 2017 Investigating Poorly Known Historic Context: Dating Minnesota’s Prehistory.  Ms. on file with Minnesota Historical Society, St. Paul, Minnesota.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/08/2021
Modified by: Linda Scott-Cummings

Were annual plant remains always available, "old wood" errors wouldn’t occur; however, because annual plant fossils are rare, archaeologists use charred food crusts to date their "single-year-of-use." Pottery is abundant compared to annual macrofossils and contains charred food crust residues (CFC’s), different from soluble food residues soaked into vessels, yielding "single-year-dates".
